label.text: Carbon Monoxide
A factory is using gas sensors to measure the concentration of carbon monoxide (CO) to ensure workers’ safety. The concentration is measured in parts per million (ppm).
The sensor measures the level of CO and displays the average concentration for the previous 60 seconds.

20 ppm
CO
The electronics of the sensor produces a voltage (V) between 0 V and 5 V, depending on the concentration of carbon monoxide.
The sensor produces 0 V when the concentration of CO is 20 ppm or less.
The sensor produces 5 V when the concentration of CO is 100 ppm or more.
Series 1:
average = 22.6 ppm
Series 2:
average = 33.6 ppm
A worker at the factory estimates that, when the concentration of CO displays as 60 ppm, the voltage produced by the sensor is 2.5 V.
What assumption has the worker made?
Sensors can experience small, random fluctuations in voltage, even when the CO concentration is constant.
What is the advantage of the sensor displaying the average concentration value when the concentration is constant?
Lower CO concentrations will be able to be detected.
Quick changes in CO concentration will be detected.
The sensor will better detect sudden fluctuations in CO concentration.
The CO concentration values displayed will not show fluctuations.
The factory workers collect the following two series of concentration values (ppm) at different times of the day.
There was the same amount of time between measurements in both series.
They calculate the average value of each series.
Which of the two average CO concentration values is likely to be a more accurate representation of the CO concentration?
Select either ‘Series 1’ or ‘Series 2’.
Explain why the average value you selected is likely to be more accurate.
There are three identical sensors in different places around a room in the factory.
One is near the workers’ desks (not a source of CO).
One is near a gas heater (a possible source of CO).
One is near an incinerator (a possible source of CO).
Before any CO source is turned on, the sensors display the average background CO concentration in the room.
Then, both the heater and the incinerator are turned on for 5 minutes.
The sensor display near the heater reaches the highest value.
What should the sensors display after the carbon monoxide sources are turned off?
The other two sensors will soon also display the same value as the sensor near the gas heater.
The value on the sensor display by the incinerator will quickly decrease to the initial background value.
The value on each sensor display will remain the same.
The concentrations recorded by the sensors will converge to the same value.
